instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437B: What is 820-3437B? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMC’s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.P5VS4RS3_EN: What is P5VS4RS3_EN? PP5VS4RS3_EN is a signal that enables the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail. When you see _EN in front of a signal name, it means that it is enabling whatever comes before the _EN when the signal is high..
definitions.S5_PWR_EN: What is S5_PWR_EN? S5_PWR_EN is a signal that turns on all S5 power rails when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .
definitions.SMC_TCK: What is SMC_TCK? SMC_TCK is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SMC_TDI: What is SMC_TDI? SMC_TDI is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SMC_TMS: What is SMC_TMS? SMC_TMS is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SMC_TDO: What is SMC_TDO? SMC_TDO is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't turn on
threads.message:
Water Damaged

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 8.19V
pp3V42:  3.431V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.430V

L5001 corroded and bad ( no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL>)
Replaced L5001: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL>: 3.431V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V_S5</SIGNAL>: 0V

@<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>:0V
<SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN</SIGNAL>: 0V


<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL>: 3.409V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>:  3.400V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>:  3.298V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>: 0.017V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>: 0V

<SIGNAL>SMC_TCK</SIGNAL>: 3.430V
<SIGNAL>SMC_TMS</SIGNAL>: 3.430V
<SIGNAL>SMC_TDO</SIGNAL>: 3.430V
<SIGNAL>SMC_TDI</SIGNAL>: 3430V

Reheat SMC: NOK
if PPBUS 8.19V so SMC is not talking to <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> right?

Next Step Rebal SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't turn on
threads.message:
Yeah, several signals point to SMC issue.
You should reball it.
If no result, change it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't turn on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't turn on
threads.message:
Hi 2Informaticos,

Just reballed the SMC and I have almost the same readings: In green the voltages which were 0V before and changed:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 8.19V
pp3V42: 3.428V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.428V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 0V
[COLOR=#00FF00]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 0.230V[/COLOR]

@<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>:0V
<SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN</SIGNAL>: 0V


<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL>: 3.408V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>: 3.397V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>: 3.298V
[COLOR=#00FF00]<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>: 0.223V[/COLOR]
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>: 0V

<SIGNAL>SMC_TCK</SIGNAL>: 3.427V
<SIGNAL>SMC_TMS</SIGNAL>: 3.427V
<SIGNAL>SMC_TDO</SIGNAL>: 3.427V
<SIGNAL>SMC_TDI</SIGNAL>: 3427V

Also when I took out the SMC, 4 pads where missing on the board, 1 was gnd and the 3 others are some NC nets (named <SIGNAL>NO_TEST</SIGNAL> Nets in the schematic )
No sure they are used, NC stands for Not Connected no?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't turn on
threads.message: Replace the SMC it?s bad. Simple as that must come from an identical donor 3437 board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't turn on
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>: 0V
[COLOR=#00FF00]<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>: 0.223V[/COLOR]
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>: 0V"
Change SMC and test them again...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't turn on
threads.message:
Replaced SMC from the same exact board:

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>:  5.049V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>:  3.354V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>:  0V
<SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>: 3.349V
[B]<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>: 2.34V[/B]
[B]<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>:  0V[/B]
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>:  3.429
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>:  3.211V

The <SIGNAL>SMC_SYS_KBDLED</SIGNAL> pad is missing on the board but this one is only used for the keyboard backlight and is attached to <CHIP>U7750</CHIP>, I'm also very surprised that this chip (<CHIP>U7750</CHIP>)  is noted as CRITICAL.
Why the keyboard backlight would be critical and preventin g the board to Start........Hummmm?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't turn on
threads.message:
CRITICAL for its function on the machine, not for general...

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> is not correct yet.
Are you using original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger?
Be sure SMC is properly soldered.
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is also lower than expected.
These two things make me doubt about SMC, or its solders...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't turn on
threads.message:
H 2Informaticos,

Yes I know that thoses to voltages are not ok that's why I've put them in [B]bold.[/B]
Yes I'm using either official 85W charger or Lab Power supply with 2 officials cords attached to it: magesafe1 and 2 and both in 85W.
I'm affraid that if I remove that smc again for reballing it will fragilize it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't turn on
threads.message:
Don't reball it.
Put good flux and reheat.
Be sure to melt the balls and gently tap it, to see it "dancing" a bit...
If still same issue, try other SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't turn on
threads.message:
I did all that but now I've lost the S5 rails now.
I think that SMC is now good for the trash.......and I don't have anymore of that board.
I think I'll just re-assemble the mba to give it back to it's owner because of the tme passed on it I'm not profitable at all.
As usual thanks for your support.
